thread.title: Stocks finish sharply higher; American Airlines to offer lower fares; Pandora stocks plummet: Business News Links
thread.title_full: Stocks finish sharply higher; American Airlines to offer lower fares; Pandora stocks plummet: Business News Links | cleveland.com

author: Ray Jablonski, Northeast Ohio Media Group
title: Stocks finish sharply higher; American Airlines to offer lower fares; Pandora stocks plummet: Business News Links
text:
Stock market news:
A tech share rally drove stocks up sharply for a second day today as earnings from companies including Microsoft beat analysts' expectations, while healthcare shares rebounded from recent losses. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 157.54 points to 17,646.70, the S&P 500 gained 22.64 points to 2,075.15 and the Nasdaq Composite added 111.81 points to 5,031.86. ( Reuters )
European stocks rallied to a two-month high after China increased stimulus, adding to optimism central banks around the world will do what's needed to support the global economy. ( Bloomberg News )
Oil futures settled with a loss today, as strength in the U.S. dollar helped pull prices down by almost 6 percent for the week. ( MarketWatch )
Business news:
American Airlines plans to offer a version of the low-fare, no-frills approach to flying that is boosting profit margins at discount carriers. ( Associated Press )
United Airlines said today it reached a tentative deal with the union representing its maintenance workers, paving the way for a wage hike and the first contract to cover technicians from both United and Continental since the airlines merged in 2010. ( Reuters )
Thomas Stemberg, whose inability to buy a printer ribbon on a holiday weekend led to the conception of Staples, the office-supply superstore he co-founded in 1985, died today at his home in Chestnut Hill, Mass. He was 66. ( Washington Post )
China has abolished its official cap on interest rates for savers and announced a further easing in monetary policy as it seeks to address slowing growth in the world's second-largest economy. ( Sky News )
Home appliances giant Whirlpool said today its profit for the third quarter increased 2 percent from last year, aided by cost and capacity reductions, acquisitions and favorable price-mix. ( RTT News )
A coalition of 24 states and a coal mining company filed lawsuits today to challenge the most significant piece of President Obama's environmental agenda, his signature climate change rule for power plants. ( The Hill )
The United Auto Workers filed today for an election by 165 skilled trades workers at the Volkswagen auto plant in Chattanooga, Tenn. ( Reuters )
Technology news:
Pandora Media hit a conspicuous sour note on Wall Street today after it tacitly acknowledged it will be hurt more than investors expected by music service competitors including Apple, Google and Spotify. ( Deadline )
Twitter chief executive and co-founder Jack Dorsey has said he is giving a third of his stock in the company, about one percent, to the employee equity pool. ( Reuters )
A Facebook engineer announced on the social media site today a bug with the app that's been draining iPhone batteries has been fixed with a new update. ( Fortune )
British telecommunications firm TalkTalk is facing new questions over whether there has been a "cover up" over one of the largest cyber hacks in British history. ( The Telegraph )
